top_picks.name: thyssenkrupp AG
top_picks.reasoning: thyssenkrupp's FY2025 turnaround to profitability and robust order intake growth (up 15% for the year, driven by Marine Systems) provide a positive base, aligning with strong recent stock momentum and an attractive P/E of 15.5.[1] However, FY2026 forecasts a net loss and sales decline amid persistent weak demand and restructuring costs at Steel Europe, tempering near-term upside in a challenging European industrials context.[1][3] Earnings growth trajectory (26% average annual rate) offers long-term potential, but volatility warrants caution.[6]
top_picks.company_overview: thyssenkrupp AG is a German industrial conglomerate operating in sectors including steel, materials services, automotive technology, marine systems, and decarbonization technologies, with a focus on ongoing transformation amid challenging market conditions.[1][3] In fiscal 2025 (ended September 30, 2025), the company achieved net income of 532 million euros (vs. prior-year loss) and adjusted EBIT of 640 million euros, though sales fell 6% to 32.8 billion euros due to demand fluctuations.[1] The stock has shown strong momentum with a 157.5% 12-month return, supported by Q4 profitability, but FY2026 guidance signals headwinds including projected net losses.[1]
key_developments: Reported Q4 FY2025 profit of 639 million euros (vs. prior-year loss of 1.06 billion euros), with adjusted EBIT up 82% to 274 million euros, though sales dropped 6% and orders 12%.[1]
FY2025 full-year net income of 532 million euros and adjusted EBIT of 640 million euros; proposes 0.15 euro per share dividend for approval at January 30, 2026 AGM (already held).[1][3]
Issued FY2026 guidance expecting net loss of 400-800 million euros (due to Steel Europe restructuring provisions) and sales flat to -2%, with mixed segment growth.[1]
catalysts: Q1 FY2026 interim report and conference call on February 12, 2026, with CEO and CFO commentary, potentially updating guidance or restructuring progress.[2][3][4]
Dividend approval confirmation post-AGM (held January 30, 2026), providing minor yield support.[1][3]
risk_factors: Projected FY2026 net loss of 400-800 million euros from Steel Europe restructuring and weak sales/orders in segments like Automotive Technology.[1]
Broader challenging macroeconomic environment, including demand fluctuations and price pressures in European steel/industrials markets.[1][3]

top_picks.name: AstraZeneca PLC
top_picks.reasoning: AstraZeneca's NYSE listing enhances liquidity and US investor access, supporting its high momentum (Alpha Score 25/25) and quality profile amid a strong 27.8% 6-month return.[1] Pipeline progress toward $80 billion 2030 revenue provides a clear growth trajectory in a favorable healthcare sector, though elevated P/E of 31.6 warrants monitoring for valuation risks.[1] Global harmonization positions AZN well in both European and US markets.
top_picks.company_overview: AstraZeneca PLC (AZN) is a global biopharmaceutical company focused on oncology, rare diseases, and bioPharmaceuticals, maintaining a strong market position with listings on the London Stock Exchange (LSE), Nasdaq Stockholm, and now the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE).[1] The company has delivered robust recent performance, with a 6-month return of +27.8% and 12-month return of +20.4%, supported by a high-quality pipeline and reiterated 2030 ambitions for $80 billion in annual revenue and 20 new medicine launches.[1] Its current metrics include a P/E ratio of 31.6, ROE of 21.7%, and an Alpha Score of 75/100, reflecting solid momentum and quality despite modest value scores.
key_developments: AstraZeneca commenced trading of its ordinary shares on the NYSE under the AZN ticker, creating a harmonized global listing structure alongside LSE and Nasdaq Stockholm, effective recently to access the world's largest capital market and broaden its investor base.[1]
The NYSE listing replaces the prior American Depositary Share (ADS) trading and transitions US dollar bonds to NYSE, with no changes to UK/Swedish listings or index memberships.[1]
Management highlighted strong pipeline momentum, with readouts representing over $10 billion in peak revenue potential, reinforcing confidence in long-term growth targets.[1]
catalysts: Pipeline readouts with >$10 billion peak revenue potential, expected to drive near-term visibility into 2030 ambitions.[1]
Potential index inclusions or increased institutional buying following NYSE listing and enhanced US liquidity.[1]
risk_factors: High P/E ratio (31.6) exposes the stock to valuation compression if growth expectations falter.[1]
Broader healthcare sector risks, including regulatory hurdles or pipeline setbacks not detailed in recent updates.[1]

top_picks.name: Vinci SA

key_developments: Reported record 2025 free cash flow of €7.01B (up from €6.81B), revenue beating estimates at €74.60B, and net profit of €4.90B, leading to a 6.4% stock jump initially and further gains to €134.20.[2][3]
Nine-month 2025 revenues rose 3.7% to €54.25B (2.0% like-for-like), with Q1 2025 revenue up 4% to €16.3B driven by 8% Concessions growth.[1]

catalysts: Q1 2026 earnings release (expected around late April, following prior patterns), potentially confirming guided revenue/EBIT growth.[1][2]
Outcomes from ongoing portfolio reviews in Concessions, Energy, and Construction units, including potential asset sales.[2]
Dividend payment post-ex-date (likely spring 2026, following €5/share proposal).[1][2]

top_picks.company_overview: Siemens Energy AG is a Germany-based energy technology company focused on power generation, grid technologies, industrial transformation, and renewables including wind turbines via its Siemens Gamesa segment, serving utilities, power producers, and industrial clients globally.[3][1] The company has delivered strong financial performance with double-digit revenue growth, record order intake, and upgraded mid-term targets through fiscal 2028, driving the stock from below €20 in early 2024 to around €152 as of early February 2026.[1][2] It operates in a favorable energy-transition context with robust demand for grid infrastructure and electrification solutions.[1]

Jefferies lifted its target to €164 from €134 on February 2, 2026, highlighting better earnings visibility and sector tailwinds from grid investments.[1]

Released strong Q4 FY2025 results in line with upgraded guidance, forecasting 11-13% comparable revenue growth and 9-11% profit margin for FY2026, while raising FY2028 targets to 14-16% margins and low-teens revenue CAGR; also plans €6bn share repurchases by FY2028 end and an early dividend.[2]
catalysts: Full FY2025 earnings release and FY2026 guidance confirmation, potentially affirming upper-end trends and dividend details.[2]
Progress on $1B US expansions and order conversions in grid/energy-transition projects.[4][5]
Further broker updates or sector M&A amid global infrastructure spending.[1]

top_picks.name: Rio Tinto Group
top_picks.reasoning: Rio Tinto's pivot to high-growth copper and lithium, combined with project execution like Oyu Tolgoi and Simandou, positions it for earnings expansion despite iron ore headwinds, supported by undervaluation metrics and H1 2025 resilience.[1][2] Strong cash conversion (60%) and disciplined capex ($4.7 billion H1) fund long-term value, with diversification mitigating commodity volatility.[1] Recent momentum and peer-lagging returns suggest market underappreciation of forward catalysts.[2]
top_picks.company_overview: Rio Tinto Group is a global mining leader focused on iron ore, aluminium, copper, and emerging areas like lithium, with strong diversification efforts amid iron ore price pressures. For H1 2025, it reported resilient Underlying EBITDA of $11.5 billion (down 5% YoY) and operating cash flow of $6.9 billion (down 2% YoY), offset by robust growth in aluminium (50% EBITDA uplift) and copper (69% uplift), despite a 13% iron ore price decline.[1] The balance sheet remains solid with high-grade credit ratings, though net debt rose to $14.6 billion post-Arcadium Lithium acquisition, supporting a 50% interim dividend payout.[1]
key_developments: Accelerated Simandou iron ore project in Guinea, targeting first shipment by November 2025, enhancing future iron ore output.[1]
Oyu Tolgoi copper mine in Mongolia ramped up 54% YoY in H1 2025 production, on track for ~500 ktpa average from 2028-2036, with lower C1 unit costs.[1]
Share price at £66.76 showed strong momentum: +5.3% (7 days), +11.6% (30 days), +44.7% (1 year), trading undervalued per DCF (19.1% discount) and P/E (14.47x vs. fair ratio 29.03x).[2]
catalysts: First Simandou iron ore shipment (November 2025), boosting production and revenue predictability.[1]
Oyu Tolgoi ramp-up milestones toward 500 ktpa copper (2028+), plus 2025 annual results on 19 February 2026.[1][5]
2026 final dividend ex-date, maintaining 50% payout policy amid improving copper/aluminium contributions.[1][4]
risk_factors: Iron ore price volatility and external disruptions like cyclones, which pressured H1 2025 EBITDA.[1]
Elevated capex ($10-11 billion mid-term) and rising net debt from acquisitions, potentially squeezing FCF if projects delay.[1]
